title: Tories copy 'shambolic' scheme that installed Corbyn as leader
text:
Tories copy 'shambolic' scheme that installed Corbyn as leader Tories copy 'shambolic' scheme that installed Corbyn as leader 6 comments 
SCOTTISH Tory leader Ruth Davidson has imported the “shambolic” system used to elect Jeremy Corbyn to pick her own Holyrood candidates. 
The Conservatives are allowing any party “supporter” to vote to determine who gets the top regional List slots for the Scottish Parliament poll. 
However, a party source warned the scheme could be open to “manipulation and infiltration”. 
Loading article content 
Labour replaced its long-standing electoral college with a new three-way system to select its new leader: party members; affiliated trade union supporters; and registered supporters. 
For the latter category, any member of the public could pay £3 to qualify for a vote, on condition of supporting the party’s values. 
The scheme led to mischief-making by Tories and far-left activists ,and thousands of individuals had to be excluded from the process. 
In some cases, it was reported that pets had been registered in an attempt to expose how easy it was to manipulate the system. 
Davidson’s party has now adopted a similar supporter scheme - minus the £3 entry fee. 
A majority of Tory MSPs are List members and the decision to open the door to a new tier of voters will have an impact on deciding next year’s Conservative representatives at Holyrood. Promoted stories 
According to the registration website, “everyone” who supports the Tories can get a vote if an online form is filled out. 
The site states: “In the past, it’s only been the members of political parties who have had a say in candidate rankings. But this time, the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party is doing things differently. We want all our supporters in every corner of Scotland to have their say.” 
In a communication to members, Davidson described the system as “the biggest exercise in popular democracy every undertaken by a political party in Scotland”. 
It is understood the new scheme is aimed at involving the tens of thousands of voters who are part of the Conservative Friends of the Union, a group set up by the Scottish Tories ahead of the referendum. 
Ballots will go out in November to supporters and members. 
However, one party insider said: “It is a good idea in principle, but there must be robust checks in place to stop manipulation and infiltration. We don’t want a winter of publicity like Labour got with its flawed system.” 
An SNP spokesperson said: “Given that in the general election the Tories received their lowest share of the vote in Scotland since the introduction of universal suffrage, it's no wonder they are trying to come up with half-baked ideas to boost their flagging membership - but copying Labour's shambolic plans probably isn't the best idea.” Share article 
A spokesman for the Scottish Conservatives said: "Everyone who registers to take part will be asked to confirm that they are a Conservative supporter and be checked against the electoral register to ensure they are who they say they are. 
"We are confident our internal checks will root out those seeking to lie and pretend to be a Scottish Conservative supporter and abuse the process.” Promoted Stories
